title: 107_hr5596
content:
Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments allow political committees of state or local candidates, as well as state or local committees of political parties, to be exempt from notifying the Secretary and reporting requirements. Effective date aligns with previous amendments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempt qualified State or local political organizations from certain notification and reporting requirements. These organizations are defined as political entities focused on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public offices. The curr_chunk discusses the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of individuals to State or local public offices or political organizations subject to state reporting laws. The curr_chunk requires information on expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved in political organizations subject to state reporting laws. The curr_chunk specifies that organizations must report certain information publicly and make it available for inspection, with exceptions for state law differences. The curr_chunk outlines the information that organizations must report publicly, including details about contributors' employers and occupations, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, and dates of contributions and expenditures. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions under which an organization can still be considered a qualified State or local political organization despite making minor errors in complying with reporting requirements. It also specifies that a federal candidate or office holder cannot be part of such an organization if they control or significantly influence its activities. The amendments made by this section shall take effect as if included in the amendments made by Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization. Taxable Income paragraph of section 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code amended. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure, amendments made to disclosure and public inspection sections. Information Returns section amended for political organizations. The section requires political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more to file annual returns with specific information for IRS purposes. Exceptions may apply for qualified State or local political organizations with higher gross receipts. The subsection outlines mandatory exceptions from filing for certain political organizations, including State or local committees, caucuses, candidate committees, national committees, and committees required to report under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Secretary may exempt organizations from filing an information return if it is deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The amendments made by this section will be effective as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 4. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, will publicize the impact of the amendments made by this Act and clarify the requirements for filing notifications or reports under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided will be included in relevant forms, instructions, notices, or guidance issued to the public. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive taxes or amounts imposed on organizations for failure to comply with requirements if due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000.

SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Amends section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code to include exempt function income regardless of segregation. 
(b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Amends section 527(j) to specify assessment and collection procedures. 
(c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Amends section 527(i)(1) to remove the requirement for duplicate written filings. 
(d) Application of Fraud Penalty.--Addresses fraudulent returns under section 7207 of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code includes changes related to fraudulent returns, electronic filing requirements for reports, and the contents of reports filed by organizations with contributions or expenditures exceeding $50,000 in a calendar year. The Internal Revenue Code amendment includes electronic filing requirements for reports by organizations with significant contributions or expenditures. The Secretary must make these reports available for public inspection online within 48 hours of filing. The entire database of reports must be searchable by specific items such as names, states, and zip codes. The Internal Revenue Code amendment mandates detailed information to be included in reports, such as organization details, contributors, recipients of expenditures, and time periods. Additionally, organizations must indicate if they intend to claim an exemption from certain requirements. Timing requirements for notifying material changes are also specified. The Internal Revenue Code amendment requires detailed information in reports, including organization details, contributors, recipients of expenditures, and time periods. Organizations must also notify material changes within 30 days to avoid penalties. Effective Dates: The amendments made by this Act apply to failures occurring on or after the date of enactment. Amendments for specific subsections have varying effective dates, ranging from the date of enactment to June 30, 2003. The amendments made by subsections (e)(2) and (e)(3) apply to reports filed after June 30, 2003. Subsection (g) amendments apply to material changes after the enactment of the Act, with a transition rule for changes within 30 days of enactment. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS ON EXISTING DISCLOSURES. Notices, reports, or returns filed before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
